.DISCUSSION...
Issued at 215 PM CST Sun Feb 12 2023

Key Messages:

- Another round of much needed rain is expected area wide on Tuesday.

- There remains decent confidence in a potential winter storm
  impacting portions of central and northeast Kansas Wednesday
  evening into Thursday.

High pressure aloft builds over the southern and central plains this 
afternoon while a weak area of sfc low pressure stretches across the 
sunflower state.  Associated high clouds have provided some effect 
on temps, however strong warm advection has won out with gusts in 
upwards of 25 mph. High temps remain on track to reach the upper 50s 
and lower 60s. As the sfc low exits this evening, winds should calm 
and become light from the northwest.  

The first anomalously strong system, currently rotating just off the 
southern CA coastline, will bring much needed rainfall to the region 
after midnight through Tuesday afternoon.  Guidance continues to be 
in good agreement in the track and location of higher precip 
amounts, lending to the definite pops mentioned Tuesday after 
sunrise. EFI and GEFS ensembles continue to indicate high PWAT 
values well above the climatological norms at 0.8 to 1 inches. 
Overall precip amounts were not changed with widespread totals from 
a half inch to 1 inch. Winds are also of concern Monday night into 
Tuesday afternoon with southerly speeds approaching advisory 
criteria of 20 to 30 mph sustained. These winds remain stout at 
around 25 mph as they shift towards the west Tuesday evening. The 
primary uncertainty to mention is the amount of mid level 
instability that develops Tuesday morning and afternoon. Lapse rates 
would be steep in the vicinity of the cold upper low so still cannot 
rule out a few afternoon thunderstorms.

The second, possibly more impactful storm system is progged to 
arrive Wednesday early evening through Thursday morning. Overall 
operational and ensemble guidance is beginning to trend the track 
of the upper low slightly further south due to a northern stream 
trough deepening further south across the Great Lakes region. This
scenario would shift the sfc low towards southern OK and 
therefore the higher precip amounts further south into central and
northeast Kansas. The 0C surface temps would also spread further 
south at a faster rate, allowing more snow to fall as oppose to 
rain early Thursday morning. Accumulating snow remains most likely
towards north central Kansas, however areas near the I-70 
corridor could end up seeing a few inches of snow as well. An 
impressive pressure gradient is shaping up to be likely area wide 
as northerly winds could gust in excess of 30 mph, resulting in 
blowing snow, reduced visibilities, and hazardous travel. If 
confidence continues to increase as models mostly remain on track,
a Winter Storm Watch will likely be needed for portions of north 
central and northeast Kansas.

Anticipate bitterly cold temps behind the front Thursday and Friday 
mornings with wind chill readings from the single digits to 10 
degrees below zero. After highs in the 20s on Thursday, a quick 
warmup should melt much of the snow with highs back in the 50s by 
Saturday.

&&

.AVIATION...(For the 00Z TAFS through 00Z Monday evening)
Issued at 532 PM CST Sun Feb 12 2023

Expect VFR conditions for the next 24 hours. A weak cold front
will switch winds to the northwest after 2Z MON, but speeds will
remain below 10 KTS. Northwest winds will become light and
variable after 12Z MON, then become southerly late Monday
afternoon.
